item.title: Why do commands require tabs in a Makefile?
item.description: When I was first learning how to write a Makefile to compile a C program, one thing that stuck me (and almost everyone who encounters it) as odd was the requirement that each command line start with a tab character ('\t'). Makefiles are used to automate repetitive tasks (such as recompiling a C/C++ program), and have a unique syntax. They are made up of rules, which consist of a “target”, a list of “dependencies”, and a series of “commands”. They look like this:
